elements.content: This paper reports the synthesis and characterization of four new compounds based on thorium and tetraethyl­diglycolamide (TEDGA), [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]­[NO3]2[H2C2O4].6H2O (1), [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2]­[H2C2O4]2.2H2O (2), [Th­(TEDGA)4]­[NO3]4.4H2O (3), and [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]­[NO3]­[HC2O4]­[H2C2O4]4.7H2O (4). All of them are obtained by successive crystallization from a unique medium containing thorium nitrate and TEDGA, in the presence of oxalic acid. Compound (1) (a = b = 18.7140(12) Å, c = 12.9212(9) Å, S.G. P42212) crystallized at first from a gel obtained by slow evaporation of the medium. When compound (1) is left in gel for a period of some weeks, it tends to disappear and to be replaced by crystals of (2) (a = 12.246(2) Å, b = 32.253(5) Å, c = 12.256(2) Å, β = 106.741(12)°, S.G. P21/n) and (3) (a = 26.5966(13) Å, b = 15.4489(7) Å, c = 18.5582(9) Å, β = 116.528(1)°, S.G. C2/c). In their turn, solids (2) and (3) disappear from the gel left for some months, and compound (1) crystallizes in mixture with compound (4) (a = 15.6611(7) Å, b = 17.9082(9) Å, c = 18.1814(7) Å, α = 89.896(2)°, β = 65.549(2)°, γ = 87.623(2), S.G. P-1). Solving the crystal structure by single crystal diffraction reveals that TEDGA is always coordinated to thorium through its three oxygen atoms. In the mixed-ligands compounds (1), (2), and (4), Th4+ is surrounded by two oxalate ligands and two TEDGA, leading to a 10-fold coordination. The dimensionality of the networks changes from linear chains (1D) (1) to isolated entities (0D) (2) or dimeric units (0D) (4). Compound (3) is formed by the assembly of 12-fold coordinated monomeric entities (0D) in which the thorium cation is surrounded by four TEDGA. This compound is the first example of such a coordination number without nitrate anion included in the coordination sphere of Th.

elements.content: Four new thorium-based compounds were synthesized by successive crystallization from a unique solution containing thorium nitrate and two complexing agents: tetraethyldiglycolamide (TEDGA) and oxalic acid. Determination of the crystal-structure highlights the high structural diversity of the studied system and shows the great ability of TEDGA to complex thorium, despite the presence of oxalic acid.
elements.clean_text: Four new thorium-based compounds were synthesized by successive crystallization from a unique solution containing thorium nitrate and two complexing agents: tetraethyldiglycolamide (TEDGA) and oxalic acid. Determination of the crystal-structure highlights the high structural diversity of the studied system and shows the great ability of TEDGA to complex thorium, despite the presence of oxalic acid.

elements.content: In the nuclear industry, the long-term radiotoxicity of the spent fuel is mainly due to plutonium and minor actinides. Therefore, to reduce the radiotoxicity of ultimate wastes, research for new generations of nuclear plants focus first on the multirecycling of plutonium and then on the recycling of minor actinides (Am in particular) with the aim, on one hand, to fabricate new Pu and U-based mixed oxides nuclear fuel pellets (MOX), and, on the other hand, to synthesize minor actinides-based transmutation targets. In the current industrial PUREX process, uranium­(VI) and plutonium­(IV) are recovered from a nitric solution containing the fission products and minor actinides by liquid–liquid phase extraction thanks to the use of tributylphosphate (TBP) in dodecane. The extracting molecules have to meet various specifications such as (i) good extraction of U and Pu from a highly concentrated nitric solution to the organic diluent, (ii) stability in aliphatic diluents, that is, resistance to radiolytic and hydrolytic degradation, (iii) ease of synthesis, and (iv) low environmental impact. The use of tributylphosphate as an extracting agent may induce the presence of residual phosphate groups in the wastes. Therefore, new extracting molecules containing only C, H, O, and N elements, fully incinerable, have been the subject of research these last years. The diglycolamide molecules (DGA) of general formula (R2N­(CO)­(CH2)­O­(CH2)­(CO)­NR2) are promising An­(IV) complexing agents due to their large number of electronegative sites. The solubility of DGA molecules and their complexing properties strongly depends on their substituent groups, R. For example, tetraoctyl­diglycolamide (TODGA) is deemed to be a very good extractant of transuranic elements in dodecane, while tetraethyldiglycolamide (TEDGA) shows good abilities for precipitating actinides and other metals in acidic conditions. Despite the possible use of DGA as extracting or complexing agents of f-elements, few structural studies have been conducted in the DGA-lanthanides or -actinides systems. The crystal structures of lanthanides complexes coordinated by DGA ligands, L, have been reported for lanthanum [La­(pic)3(L2) with L containing RR′ = Et and Ph; (LaL3)­(La­(NO3)6) with L substituted by R = i-Pr or by i-Bu], for cerium and ytterbium [(CeL)­(Ce­(NO3)6)­(CH3OH)­(C4H10O), (YbL)­(NO3)3 where L is a tris-DGA ligand and (YbL3)­(NO3)4 with L holding R = i-Pr], and for the heavy lanthanides series (Ln = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, and Lu) [(LnL3)­(NO3)3·4H2O with L substituted by R = Et]. Main crystal structures of the actinides-DGA complexes were reported for An-yl salts with a DGA/actinyle ratio of 1:1 [(UO2L)­X2 with L carrying R = i-Pr or R = i-Bu and X = Cl– or NO3 –] or 1:2 [(UO2L2)­(X)2, (PuO2L2)­(X)2, and (NpO2L2)­(X) with R = Me and X = ClO4 –]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the crystal structures reported in the An­(IV)-DGA system have remained limited to (PuIVL3)­(NO3)3·MCN and (PuIVL3)­(NO3)3·ETOH with R = Me attached to L8, so far.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the nuclear industry, the long-term radiotoxicity of the spent fuel is mainly due to plutonium and minor actinides. Therefore, to reduce the radiotoxicity of ultimate wastes, research for new generations of nuclear plants focus first on the multirecycling of plutonium and then on the recycling of minor actinides (Am in particular) with the aim, on one hand, to fabricate new Pu and U-based mixed oxides nuclear fuel pellets (MOX), and, on the other hand, to synthesize minor actinides-based transmutation targets. In the current industrial PUREX process, uranium(VI) and plutonium(IV) are recovered from a nitric solution containing the fission products and minor actinides by liquid-liquid phase extraction thanks to the use of tributylphosphate (TBP) in dodecane. The extracting molecules have to meet various specifications such as (i) good extraction of U and Pu from a highly concentrated nitric solution to the organic diluent, (ii) stability in aliphatic diluents, that is, resistance to radiolytic and hydrolytic degradation, (iii) ease of synthesis, and (iv) low environmental impact. The use of tributylphosphate as an extracting agent may induce the presence of residual phosphate groups in the wastes. Therefore, new extracting molecules containing only C, H, O, and N elements, fully incinerable, have been the subject of research these last years. The diglycolamide molecules (DGA) of general formula (R2N(CO)(CH2)O(CH2)(CO)NR2) are promising An(IV) complexing agents due to their large number of electronegative sites. The solubility of DGA molecules and their complexing properties strongly depends on their substituent groups, R. For example, tetraoctyldiglycolamide (TODGA) is deemed to be a very good extractant of transuranic elements in dodecane, while tetraethyldiglycolamide (TEDGA) shows good abilities for precipitating actinides and other metals in acidic conditions. Despite the possible use of DGA as extracting or complexing agents of f-elements, few structural studies have been conducted in the DGA-lanthanides or -actinides systems. The crystal structures of lanthanides complexes coordinated by DGA ligands, L, have been reported for lanthanum [La(pic)3(L2) with L containing RR' = Et and Ph; (LaL3)(La(NO3)6) with L substituted by R = i-Pr or by i-Bu], for cerium and ytterbium [(CeL)(Ce(NO3)6)(CH3OH)(C4H10O), (YbL)(NO3)3 where L is a tris-DGA ligand and (YbL3)(NO3)4 with L holding R = i-Pr], and for the heavy lanthanides series (Ln = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, and Lu) [(LnL3)(NO3)3⋅4H2O with L substituted by R = Et]. Main crystal structures of the actinides-DGA complexes were reported for An-yl salts with a DGA/actinyle ratio of 1:1 [(UO2L)X2 with L carrying R = i-Pr or R = i-Bu and X = Cl- or NO3 -] or 1:2 [(UO2L2)(X)2, (PuO2L2)(X)2, and (NpO2L2)(X) with R = Me and X = ClO4 -]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the crystal structures reported in the An(IV)-DGA system have remained limited to (PuIVL3)(NO3)3⋅MCN and (PuIVL3)(NO3)3⋅ETOH with R = Me attached to L8, so far.

elements.content: This paper reports the influence of tetraethyl­diglycolamide (TEDGA) on crystallization in the An­(IV)-oxalate system, where Th­(IV) was used as an analog of Pu­(IV). Under evaporation, the presence of TEDGA leads to the crystal growth of four new compounds hereafter named (1), (2), (3), and (4) whose crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. This paper aims to describe and compare the structural arrangement of these compounds and to report the spectroscopic study of compound (3), obtained as a pure phase.
elements.clean_text: This paper reports the influence of tetraethyldiglycolamide (TEDGA) on crystallization in the An(IV)-oxalate system, where Th(IV) was used as an analog of Pu(IV). Under evaporation, the presence of TEDGA leads to the crystal growth of four new compounds hereafter named (1), (2), (3), and (4) whose crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. This paper aims to describe and compare the structural arrangement of these compounds and to report the spectroscopic study of compound (3), obtained as a pure phase.

elements.content:
Caution! Thorium nitrate (Th­(NO3)4·4H2O) is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant, so precautions with suitable care and protection for handling such substances have been followed.

Reactants

Th­(NO3)4·4H2O was purchased from Prolabo (99%), oxalic acid from Alfa Aesar (98%), and TEDGA from INABATA Pharmasynthèse SA (>99%).

Synthesis of [Th­(TEDGA)<sub>2</sub>(C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)]­[NO<sub>3</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[H<sub>2</sub>C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>]·6H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>), [Th­(TEDGA)<sub>2</sub>(C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]­[H<sub>2</sub>C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>]<sub>2</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>), [Th­(TEDGA)<sub>4</sub>[NO<sub>3</sub>]<sub>4</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>), and [Th<sub>2</sub>(C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>(TEDGA)<sub>4</sub>]­[NO<sub>3</sub>]­[HC<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>]­[H<sub>2</sub>C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>]<sub>4</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

Thorium nitrate (0.2 mmol) and TEDGA (1.4 mmol) were added in 10 mL of deionized water. The solution was heated at 50 °C for 2 h; then a solution of oxalic acid (1.4 mmol in 10 mL of deionized water) was added within 2 h. A colorless solution was obtained after all reactants were added and was left under the hood for slow evaporation. After 10 days at room temperature, a viscous solution containing crystals of (1) was obtained. These crystals of (1) have to be retained into their solution, otherwise a rapid degradation is observed.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

  Caution!  Thorium nitrate (Th(NO3)4⋅4H2O) is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant, so precautions with suitable care and protection for handling such substances have been followed. 

Reactants

Th(NO3)4⋅4H2O was purchased from Prolabo (99%), oxalic acid from Alfa Aesar (98%), and TEDGA from INABATA Pharmasynthèse SA (>99%).

Synthesis of [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)][NO3]2[H2C2O4]⋅6H2O (1), [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2][H2C2O4]2⋅2H2O (2), [Th(TEDGA)4[NO3]4⋅4H2O (3), and [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4][NO3][HC2O4][H2C2O4]4⋅7H2O (4)

Thorium nitrate (0.2 mmol) and TEDGA (1.4 mmol) were added in 10 mL of deionized water. The solution was heated at 50 °C for 2 h; then a solution of oxalic acid (1.4 mmol in 10 mL of deionized water) was added within 2 h. A colorless solution was obtained after all  reactants were added and was left under the hood for slow evaporation. After 10 days at room temperature, a viscous solution containing crystals of (1) was obtained. These crystals of (1) have to be retained into their solution, otherwise a rapid degradation is observed.

elements.content: When the vial containing (1) embedded in gel is left open to air, at ambient temperature, in absence of sealing, oxalic acid crystallizes. The vial was then sealed to prevent further evaporation. After 5 weeks at ambient temperature, single-crystals of compound (1) were no more found, while single-crystals of (2) and (3) had grown in gel. In their turn, solids (2) and (3) disappeared from the gel left for four months at room temperature, and compound (1) crystallized again in mixture with compound (4). It must be noted that this crystallization sequence is reproducible except for the formation of (2), which has occurred just once and could not be reproduced.

The vial was then sealed to prevent further evaporation. After 5 weeks at ambient temperature, single-crystals of compound (1) were no more found, while single-crystals of (2) and (3) had grown in gel. In their turn, solids (2) and (3) disappeared from the gel left for four months at room temperature, and compound (1) crystallized again in mixture with compound (4). It must be noted that this crystallization sequence is reproducible except for the formation of (2), which has occurred just once and could not be reproduced.

elements.content: These transformations are accompanied by a morphological change characteristic of the crystals (). Indeed, the compound (1) displays a rod-like shape (a,c), while intermediate compounds (2) and (3) have a platelet shape (b), the smallest single crystals being typical of compound (2) and the biggest corresponding to (3). Compound (4) displays a block type morphology (c).

Indeed, the compound (1) displays a rod-like shape (a,c), while intermediate compounds (2) and (3) have a platelet shape (b), the smallest single crystals being typical of compound (2) and the biggest corresponding to (3). Compound (4) displays a block type morphology (c).

elements.content: Micrographs of the single-crystals appearing in a viscous solution containing thorium nitrate, TEDGA, and oxalic acid left at room temperature. (a) After 10 days, compound (1), in red, crystallizes; (b) five weeks later, a mixture of (2), in violet, and (3), in green, is formed; (c) after four months, a mixture of rod-like crystals (1), in red, and blocks (4), in yellow, is obtained.

(a) After 10 days, compound (1), in red, crystallizes; (b) five weeks later, a mixture of (2), in violet, and (3), in green, is formed; (c) after four months, a mixture of rod-like crystals (1), in red, and blocks (4), in yellow, is obtained.

elements.content: Several trials were conducted to understand the crystallization sequence. In particular, the effect of the temperature on the transformation (1) → (2) was studied. Several viscous solutions containing compound (1) were synthesized then were kept sealed at 5 °C, 17 °C, 20 °C, and 25 °C. Despite a careful monitoring on the solutions at these different temperatures, compound (2) was not obtained. Crystals (1) remain stable in solution except at 25 °C, which is a temperature inducing a degradation. Neither (3) nor (4) was obtained through the use of these temperatures, which let us assume that their formation most probably occurs through the dissolution of small crystals of (1), at higher temperature than 25 °C.

Despite a careful monitoring on the solutions at these different temperatures, compound (2) was not obtained. Crystals (1) remain stable in solution except at 25 °C, which is a temperature inducing a degradation. Neither (3) nor (4) was obtained through the use of these temperatures, which let us assume that their formation most probably occurs through the dissolution of small crystals of (1), at higher temperature than 25 °C.

elements.content: Compound (3) was obtained as a pure phase by adding thorium nitrate (0.2 mmol), TEDGA (0.8 mmol), and oxalic acid (50 mg) to 10 mL of deionized water, at room temperature. Solid oxalic acid was used in place of oxalic acid solution to favor slow diffusion and then achieve a better crystal growth. The colorless solution obtained after adding all the reactants was left under the hood. After 10 days, a precipitate matching the X-ray powder diffraction pattern of compound (3) was obtained (Figure S2) with a yield of 25%. This pure powder was afterward used to perform further chemical analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Pure [Th(TEDGA)4[NO3]4⋅4H2O (3)

Compound (3) was obtained as a pure phase by adding thorium nitrate (0.2 mmol), TEDGA (0.8 mmol), and oxalic acid (50 mg) to 10 mL of deionized water, at room temperature. Solid oxalic acid was used in place of oxalic acid solution to favor slow diffusion and then achieve a better crystal growth. The colorless solution obtained after adding all the reactants was left under the hood. After 10 days, a precipitate matching the X-ray powder diffraction pattern of compound (3) was obtained (Figure S2) with a yield of 25%. This pure powder was afterward used to perform further chemical analysis.

elements.content: The collection of the diffraction data was performed at 293 K for (2), and at 100 K for the compounds (1), (3), and (4), on a Bruker DUO-APEX2 CCD area detector diffractometer using Mo–Kα radiation (λ= 0.71073 Å) with an Incoatec microsource. The data reduction was accomplished using SAINT V7.53a. The substantial redundancy in data allowed a semi empirical absorption correction (SADABS V2.10) to be applied on the basis of multiple measurements of equivalent reflections. Because of the low stability of (1), data were collected with 5 s frame exposure, while data for (2), (3), and (4) were recorded with 20 s frame exposure. The structures were solved by direct methods, developed by successive difference Fourier syntheses, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on all F2 data using OLEX2 and SHELXL program software. Hydrogen atoms of the TEDGA were included in calculated positions and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules and oxalic acid parts were found on Fourier-difference maps. The low quality of the data for the compound (2) has led to consider several C–O distance constrains for free oxalic part and an isotropic thermal agitation factor for all C, O, N, and H atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal Diffraction

The collection of the diffraction data was performed at 293 K for (2), and at 100 K for the compounds (1), (3), and (4), on a Bruker DUO-APEX2 CCD area detector diffractometer using Mo-Kα radiation (λ= 0.71073 Å) with an Incoatec microsource. The data reduction was accomplished using SAINT V7.53a. The substantial redundancy in data allowed a semi empirical absorption correction (SADABS V2.10) to be applied on the basis of multiple measurements of equivalent reflections. Because of the low stability of (1), data were collected with 5 s frame exposure, while data for (2), (3), and (4) were recorded with 20 s frame exposure. The structures were solved by direct methods, developed by successive difference Fourier syntheses, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on all F2 data using OLEX2 and SHELXL program software. Hydrogen atoms of the TEDGA were included in calculated positions and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules and oxalic acid parts were found on Fourier-difference maps. The low quality of the data for the compound (2) has led to consider several C-O distance constrains for free oxalic part and an isotropic thermal agitation factor for all C, O, N, and H atoms.

elements.content: Selected crystallographic data are reported . The CIF files of compounds 1–4 are provided as Supporting Information under the CCDC numbers 1855523 for (1), 1855524 for (2), 1855526 for (3), 1855525 for (4).

X-ray powder diffraction was performed on Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (LynxEye detector) in a Bragg–Brentano θ–θ mode using Cu–Kα radiation. Each powder pattern was recorded within an angular range of 5–70° in 2θ, with steps of 0.02° and counting time of 0.5 s per step.
elements.clean_text:
Powder Diffraction

X-ray powder diffraction was performed on Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (LynxEye detector) in a Bragg-Brentano θ-θ mode using Cu-Kα radiation. Each powder pattern was recorded within an angular range of 5-70° in 2θ, with steps of 0.02° and counting time of 0.5 s per step.

elements.content: Figures S1–S4 display the X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the pure compounds (1), (3) and the mixtures (1) + (4) and (2) + (3) and the full pattern matching performed with FullProf. A Pseudo-Voigt function was used as profile function for all refinements. The refinement involved the fit of a fifth order polynomial as background, a zero shift parameter, the lattice parameters, five profile parameters (U, V, W, X, and a mixing coefficient η), and two asymmetric parameters. The asymmetry correction was performed using a Berar-Baldinozzi function as implemented in FullProf. The crystals of (1) are not stable in air and could not be extracted from the gel to be correctly sampled (no crushing) for powder X-ray diffraction. Intensities are then biased by preferred orientation effects.

The refinement involved the fit of a fifth order polynomial as background, a zero shift parameter, the lattice parameters, five profile parameters (U, V, W, X, and a mixing coefficient η), and two asymmetric parameters. The asymmetry correction was performed using a Berar-Baldinozzi function as implemented in FullProf. The crystals of (1) are not stable in air and could not be extracted from the gel to be correctly sampled (no crushing) for powder X-ray diffraction. Intensities are then biased by preferred orientation effects.

elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy

Infrared spectroscopy was performed with a PerkinElmer Spectrum Two spectrometer equipped with a single reflection attenuated total reflectance (ATR), between 4000 and 400 cm-1, with a 1 cm-1 resolution.

elements.content:
Thermal analysis was performed on a thermoanalyser 92 SETARAM TGA up to 900 °C, in air, with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1.

Results and DiscussionStructural DescriptionCrystal Structure of (<bold>1</bold>)

Compound (1) [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]­[NO3]2[H2C2O4]·6H2O crystallizes in the tetragonal noncentrosymmetric space group P42212 (n°94). The thorium­(IV) ions are surrounded by ten oxygen atoms, which form a bicapped square antiprism (a). Six oxygen atoms are provided by two tridentate TEDGA ligands, and four oxygen atoms come from two bidentate oxalate ligands leading to structural building units (SBU) of formula [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2]. The TEDGA ligands are planar and possess two ethyl groups in a syn–syn conformation and two ethyl groups in a syn–anti conformation (b). The Th–O distances range between 2.421(6) and 2.648(6) Å, the longest Th–O distances being representative of the Th–Oether bonds and the shortest of Th–Ocarbonyl. The Th–Ooxalate distances have intermediate values close to those of the Th–Ocarbonyl bonds ().
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

Thermal analysis was performed on a thermoanalyser 92 SETARAM TGA up to 900 °C, in air, with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1.

Results and Discussion

Structural Description

Crystal Structure of (1)

Compound (1) [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)][NO3]2[H2C2O4]⋅6H2O crystallizes in the tetragonal noncentrosymmetric space group P42212 (n°94). The thorium(IV) ions are surrounded by ten oxygen atoms, which form a bicapped square antiprism (a). Six oxygen atoms are provided by two tridentate TEDGA ligands, and four oxygen atoms come from two bidentate oxalate ligands leading to structural building units (SBU) of formula [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2]. The TEDGA ligands are planar and possess two ethyl groups in a syn-syn conformation and two ethyl groups in a syn-anti conformation (b). The Th-O distances range between 2.421(6) and 2.648(6) Å, the longest Th-O distances being representative of the Th-Oether bonds and the shortest of Th-Ocarbonyl. The Th-Ooxalate distances have intermediate values close to those of the Th-Ocarbonyl bonds ().

elements.content: Crystal structure of [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]­[NO3]2[H2C2O4]·6H2O (1). (a) 10-fold coordination of Th. (b) Syn–syn and syn–anti conformation of the TEDGA ethyl-groups. (c) [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]2+ ∞ chains running along the c axis and maintained in a three-dimensional arrangement by means of a H-bond network (blue dotted lines) involving the nitrate anions, (d) oxalic acid and water molecules. Legend: Th4+ coordination polyhedra are in purple, C in gray, O in red, and N in blue. The black arrows show the orientation of the ethyl groups over the plane defined by N–C–C atoms: full line, up; dotted line, down. The TEDGA molecules were removed for clarity in the H-network representation.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)][NO3]2[H2C2O4]⋅6H2O (1). (a) 10-fold coordination of Th. (b) Syn-syn and syn-anti conformation of the TEDGA ethyl-groups. (c) [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]2+ ∞ chains running along the c axis and maintained in a three-dimensional arrangement by means of a H-bond network (blue dotted lines) involving the nitrate anions, (d) oxalic acid and water molecules. Legend: Th4+ coordination polyhedra are in purple, C in gray, O in red, and N in blue. The black arrows show the orientation of the ethyl groups over the plane defined by N-C-C atoms: full line, up; dotted line, down. The TEDGA molecules were removed for clarity in the H-network representation.

The two oxalate ligands, ox1, twisted by 90° on both sides of the SBU, are related by the four-fold axis. Their sharing in a bis-bidentate μ2-η2:η2 mode between two SBU forms cationic chains, [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]2+ ∞, running along the c axis (c,d). The distance Th–Th through the oxalate ligands is equal to 6.490 Å and is similar to the one encountered in the literature for most of the 10-fold coordinated Thorium­(IV) compounds connected by a bis-bidentate μ2-oxalate. In (1), the [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]2+ ∞ chains are linear with successive Th–Th–Th atoms forming an angle equal to 180°, close to the one found in (NH4)4Th­(C2O4)4·4H2O, while in compounds M4[An­(C2O4)4]·nH2O (An = Th, M = K, N2H5, n = 4 ; M = C­(NH2)3, n = 2; M = Na, n = 5.5 – An = U, M = K, n = 4; M = C­(NH2)3, n = 2 and An = Np, Pu, M = C­(NH2)3, n = 2) the [An­(C2O4)4]4+ ∞ chains are corrugated with a An–An–An angle close to 158°.
elements.clean_text: The two oxalate ligands, ox1, twisted by 90° on both sides of the SBU, are related by the four-fold axis. Their sharing in a bis-bidentate μ2-η2:η2 mode between two SBU forms cationic chains, [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]2+ ∞, running along the c axis (c,d). The distance Th-Th through the oxalate ligands is equal to 6.490 Å and is similar to the one encountered in the literature for most of the 10-fold coordinated Thorium(IV) compounds connected by a bis-bidentate μ2-oxalate. In (1), the [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]2+ ∞ chains are linear with successive Th-Th-Th atoms forming an angle equal to 180°, close to the one found in (NH4)4Th(C2O4)4⋅4H2O, while in compounds M4[An(C2O4)4]⋅nH2O (An = Th, M = K, N2H5, n = 4 ; M = C(NH2)3, n = 2; M = Na, n = 5.5 - An = U, M = K, n = 4; M = C(NH2)3, n = 2 and An = Np, Pu, M = C(NH2)3, n = 2) the [An(C2O4)4]4+ ∞ chains are corrugated with a An-An-An angle close to 158°.

elements.content: The stability of the three-dimensional arrangement is only ensured by a hydrogen-bonds network involving the free nitrates, found along the [110] and [−110] directions, the free water molecules and the free oxalic acid molecules, found on the two-fold axes, parallel to c axis (d).
elements.clean_text: The stability of the three-dimensional arrangement is only ensured by a hydrogen-bonds network involving the free nitrates, found along the [110] and [-110] directions, the free water molecules and the free oxalic acid molecules, found on the two-fold axes, parallel to c axis (d).

elements.content: Compound (2), [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2]­[H2C2O4]2·2H2O, crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n (n°14). The ten oxygen atoms surrounding Th4+ form a bicapped square antiprism polyhedron (a). The 10-fold coordination involves six oxygen atoms coming from two tridentate TEDGA ligands and four oxygen atoms provided by two bidentate oxalate ligands, leading to structural building units (SBU) with the same formula as observed in (1), [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2] (b). The Th–O distances range from 2.427(10) to 2.707(10) Å, the longest Th–O distances being representative of the Th–Oether bonds (2.7 Å) and the shortest of the Th–Ocarbonyl and Th–Ooxalate ones (2.4 Å) ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of (2)

Compound (2), [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2][H2C2O4]2⋅2H2O, crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n (n°14). The ten oxygen atoms surrounding Th4+ form a bicapped square antiprism polyhedron (a). The 10-fold coordination involves six oxygen atoms coming from two tridentate TEDGA ligands and four oxygen atoms provided by two bidentate oxalate ligands, leading to structural building units (SBU) with the same formula as observed in (1), [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2] (b). The Th-O distances range from 2.427(10) to 2.707(10) Å, the longest Th-O distances being representative of the Th-Oether bonds (2.7 Å) and the shortest of the Th-Ocarbonyl and Th-Ooxalate ones (2.4 Å) ().

elements.content: Crystal structure of [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2]­[H2C2O4]2·2H2O (2). (a) 10-fold coordination of Th. (b) Syn–syn conformation and syn–anti conformation of the TEDGA ethyl-groups. (c) [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2] entities maintained in a two-dimensional arrangement by means of a H-bond network (blue dotted lines) involving two oxalic acid and two water molecules. (d) [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2]­[H2C2O4]2[H2O]2 stacking along b direction. Legend: Th4+ coordination polyhedra are in purple, C in gray, O in red, and N in blue. The black arrows show the orientation of the ethyl groups over the plane defined by N–C–C atoms; full line, up; dotted line, down. The TEDGA molecules were removed for clarity in the H-network representation.
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2][H2C2O4]2⋅2H2O (2). (a) 10-fold coordination of Th. (b) Syn-syn conformation and syn-anti conformation of the TEDGA ethyl-groups. (c) [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2] entities maintained in a two-dimensional arrangement by means of a H-bond network (blue dotted lines) involving two oxalic acid and two water molecules. (d) [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2][H2C2O4]2[H2O]2 stacking along b direction. Legend: Th4+ coordination polyhedra are in purple, C in gray, O in red, and N in blue. The black arrows show the orientation of the ethyl groups over the plane defined by N-C-C atoms; full line, up; dotted line, down. The TEDGA molecules were removed for clarity in the H-network representation.

elements.content: The two TEDGA ligands, TEDGA 1 and TEDGA 2, show an almost planar geometry. All the ethyl groups are in a syn–anti conformation except in TEDGA 2 in which the C3 atoms half occupy two crystallographic positions, which leads to two orientations of the C3–C4 ethyl groups and two conformations, syn–anti and syn–syn (b).
elements.clean_text: The two TEDGA ligands, TEDGA 1 and TEDGA 2, show an almost planar geometry. All the ethyl groups are in a syn-anti conformation except in TEDGA 2 in which the C3 atoms half occupy two crystallographic positions, which leads to two orientations of the C3-C4 ethyl groups and two conformations, syn-anti and syn-syn (b).

elements.content: The two oxalate groups coordinated to Th4+, ox1a and ox1b, act as terminal bidentate ligands, which lead to isolated entities (0D compound). The [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2] entities are assembled by means of a hydrogen bonds network involving two free oxalic acid (ox2 and ox3) and two water molecules that form [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2]­[H2C2O4]2[H2O]2 layers parallel to (101) (c). The layers are stacked in b direction, and the three-dimensional arrangement is maintained thanks to Van der Walls interaction between the TEDGA molecules (d). The absence of strong bonding interaction between the [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2]­[H2C2O4]2[H2O]2 layers most probably explain the lack of stability of compound (2) and the difficulties in reproducing its synthesis. It also must be noted that it is the only compound of the series with no nitrate included in the crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: The two oxalate groups coordinated to Th4+, ox1a and ox1b, act as terminal bidentate ligands, which lead to isolated entities (0D compound). The [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2] entities are assembled by means of a hydrogen bonds network involving two free oxalic acid (ox2 and ox3) and two water molecules that form [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2][H2C2O4]2[H2O]2 layers parallel to (101) (c). The layers are stacked in b direction, and the three-dimensional arrangement is maintained thanks to Van der Walls interaction between the TEDGA molecules (d). The absence of strong bonding interaction between the [Th(TEDGA)2(C2O4)2][H2C2O4]2[H2O]2 layers most probably explain the lack of stability of compound (2) and the difficulties in reproducing its synthesis. It also must be noted that it is the only compound of the series with no nitrate included in the crystal structure.

elements.content: Compound (3), [Th­(TEDGA)4]­[NO3]4·4H2O, crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (n°15). The coordination sphere of Th4+ differs from the series in that Th4+ is 12-fold coordinated by four tridentate TEDGA and does not include oxalate group (a). One may note that 12-fold coordinated Th4+ remain more rarely encountered than 8–10-fold coordinated Th4+.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of (3)

Compound (3), [Th(TEDGA)4][NO3]4⋅4H2O, crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (n°15). The coordination sphere of Th4+ differs from the series in that Th4+ is 12-fold coordinated by four tridentate TEDGA and does not include oxalate group (a). One may note that 12-fold coordinated Th4+ remain more rarely encountered than 8-10-fold coordinated Th4+.

elements.content: Crystal structure of [Th­(TEDGA)4]­[NO3]4·4H2O (3). (a) 12-fold coordination of Th. (b) Syn–anti conformation of the TEDGA ethyl-groups. (c) [Th­(TEDGA)4]4+ entities surrounded by four nitrate anions, and (d) maintained in a three-dimensional arrangement thanks to the electrostatic interactions and the H-bond network (blue dotted lines) between the nitrate anions and the water molecules. Legend: Th4+ coordination polyhedra are in purple, C in gray, O in red, and N in blue. The black arrows show the syn–anti orientation of the ethyl groups. The TEDGA molecules were removed for clarity in the H-network representation.
elements.clean_text: 4  Crystal structure of [Th(TEDGA)4][NO3]4⋅4H2O (3). (a) 12-fold coordination of Th. (b) Syn-anti conformation of the TEDGA ethyl-groups. (c) [Th(TEDGA)4]4+ entities surrounded by four nitrate anions, and (d) maintained in a three-dimensional arrangement thanks to the electrostatic interactions and the H-bond network (blue dotted lines) between the nitrate anions and the water molecules. Legend: Th4+ coordination polyhedra are in purple, C in gray, O in red, and N in blue. The black arrows show the syn-anti orientation of the ethyl groups. The TEDGA molecules were removed for clarity in the H-network representation.

elements.content: The experimental Th–O distances (2.500(1) to 2.681(1) Å, ) are shorter than the Th–O distances calculated for Th­(TMDGA)4 (TMDGA: tetramethyl­diglycolamide) previously reported in literature (2.87 Å), which reflects the strong interaction existing between the Th4+ cations and TEDGA molecules.
elements.clean_text: The experimental Th-O distances (2.500(1) to 2.681(1) Å, ) are shorter than the Th-O distances calculated for Th(TMDGA)4 (TMDGA: tetramethyldiglycolamide) previously reported in literature (2.87 Å), which reflects the strong interaction existing between the Th4+ cations and TEDGA molecules.

elements.content: Because of their large number around Th4+, the TEDGA molecules show different geometrical characteristics in compound (3) than in compounds (1), (2), and (4). On one hand, the dihedral angles between the planes including the amide functions are higher (Table S8); on the other hand, all the ethyl groups are in a syn–anti conformation (b).

elements.content: Compound (4), [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]­[NO3]­[HC2O4]­[H2C2O4]4·7H2O, crystallizes in a triclinic P-1 space group. The cationic environment is similar for the two independent thorium, which are surrounded by ten oxygen atoms, forming a bicapped square antiprism (a). As observed in compounds (1) and (2), six oxygen atoms come from the TEDGA ligands and four come from two oxalate ligands (b).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of (4)

Compound (4), [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4][NO3][HC2O4][H2C2O4]4⋅7H2O, crystallizes in a triclinic P-1 space group. The cationic environment is similar for the two independent thorium, which are surrounded by ten oxygen atoms, forming a bicapped square antiprism (a). As observed in compounds (1) and (2), six oxygen atoms come from the TEDGA ligands and four come from two oxalate ligands (b).

elements.content: Crystal structure of [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]­[NO3]­[HC2O4]­[H2C2O4]4·7H2O (4). (a) 10-fold coordination of Th. (b) Syn–syn and syn–anti conformation of the TEDGA ethyl-groups. (c) Dimeric units [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]2+ surrounded by the nitrate groups and (d) maintained in a three-dimensional arrangement by means of a H-bond network (blue dotted lines) between the nitrate anions, oxalic acid, and water molecules. Legend: Th4+ coordination polyhedra are in purple, C in gray, O in red, and N in blue. The black arrows show the orientation of the ethyl groups over the plane defined by N–C–C atoms: full line, up; dotted line, down. The TEDGA molecules were removed for clarity in the H-network representation.

elements.content: The oxalates Ox1 coordinate the thorium cations in a bidentate mode η2, while the oxalates Ox2 are in a bridging bis-bidentate mode μ2-η2:η2, which leads to the formation of isolated dimeric units [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]2+ (c,d). The Th–Ooxalate distances belong to the range 2.416(2)–2.509(2) Å, the longest distances being provided by the bridging oxalates Ox2 (d mean = 2.500(8) Å) and the shortest by the terminal oxalates Ox1 (d mean = 2.422(7) Å). As previously observed in compounds (1) and (2), the Th–Ocarbonyl distances values are close to the Th–Ooxalate distances (d mean = 2.463(15) Å), while the Th–Oether bond-lengths are longer (d mean = 2.657(30) Å) ().

elements.content: The dimeric units [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]2+ are part from a hydrogen-bond network, which involves free water molecules and free oxalic acids. To respect neutrality, one oxalate acids of compound (4) must be partially deprotonated. It appears from the Fourier-difference maps that no residual density is observed in the neighborhood of the planar oxalate Ox3, which is the most probably this peculiar one. The monoprotonated oxalates, Ox3, are hydrogen bonded to four water molecules (Ow1, Ow2, Ow3, Ow4) themselves linked to the [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]2+ dimeric units by means of the terminal oxalate groups Ox1. That forms cationic zigzag chains with formula [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]­[HC2O4]­[H2O]4 + (d).

elements.content: Half of the dimeric units [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]2+ from the chains are surrounded by two nitrate anions, which belong to anionic clusters with formula [(NO3)­(H2O)3]− (c,d). The three-dimensional arrangement of compound (3) is ensured by electrostatic interaction between the cationic chains and anionic clusters, [(NO3)­(H2O)3]−, and by hydrogen bonding between the chains, the clusters, and the free residual oxalic acids, Ox4, Ox5, Ox6, and Ox7. While oxalates Ox5 and Ox6 participate to the linkage of the cationic chains within the plane, oxalates Ox4 and Ox7 are hydrogen bonded to the clusters perpendicularly to this plan by means of the and water molecules Ow5 and Ow7.

While oxalates Ox5 and Ox6 participate to the linkage of the cationic chains within the plane, oxalates Ox4 and Ox7 are hydrogen bonded to the clusters perpendicularly to this plan by means of the and water molecules Ow5 and Ow7.

elements.content: Although the connectivity of the networks differs between (1), (2), and (4), the first coordination sphere of the thorium cation remains equivalent in these three compounds. The actinide is located at the center of a bicapped square antiprism (CN: 10) whose summits of each square faces are made of two carbonyl oxygen atoms from one TEDGA and two oxygen atoms coming from two different oxalate groups. The two ether oxygen atoms of the TEDGA ligands occupy the capping positions. Unlike in (1), (2), and (4), the actinide in compound (3) presents a 12-fold coordination forming an icosahedron whose summits are composed by the oxygen atoms of TEDGA parts, without oxalate’s bonding. An overview of the literature indicates that 12-coordinated thorium atoms are found in thorium nitrate compounds [Th­(NO3)6]­[L] with L = bipyridinium, oxadiazole, phosphonium, oxonium, or [Th­(NO3)3–5]­[M] with M = phosphate, sulfoxide, and phosphine but remain rarely encountered (only 26 results in the conquest database). To the best of our knowledge, it is the first compound presenting such coordination number without any nitrate anion belonging to the coordination sphere. The presence of TEDGA in the coordination sphere of each of the compounds shows the great complexing behavior and stability of Th­(TEDGA) x complexes despite the presence of oxalic acid, which is known to form insoluble and stable thorium oxalate Th­(C2O4)2·nH2O.
elements.clean_text:
Thorium Coordination

Although the connectivity of the networks differs between (1), (2), and (4), the first coordination sphere of the thorium cation remains equivalent in these three compounds. The actinide is located at the center of a bicapped square antiprism (CN: 10) whose summits of each square faces are made of two carbonyl oxygen atoms from one TEDGA and two oxygen atoms coming from two different oxalate groups. The two ether oxygen atoms of the TEDGA ligands occupy the capping positions. Unlike in (1), (2), and (4), the actinide in compound (3) presents a 12-fold coordination forming an icosahedron whose summits are composed by the oxygen atoms of TEDGA parts, without oxalate's bonding. An overview of the literature indicates that 12-coordinated thorium atoms are found in thorium nitrate compounds [Th(NO3)6][L] with L = bipyridinium, oxadiazole, phosphonium, oxonium, or [Th(NO3)3-5][M] with M = phosphate, sulfoxide, and phosphine but remain rarely encountered (only 26 results in the conquest database). To the best of our knowledge, it is the first compound presenting such coordination number without any nitrate anion belonging to the coordination sphere. The presence of TEDGA in the coordination sphere of each of the compounds shows the great complexing behavior and stability of Th(TEDGA) x  complexes despite the presence of oxalic acid, which is known to form insoluble and stable thorium oxalate Th(C2O4)2⋅nH2O.

elements.content: The Th–Oether mean distances (2.622(2) to 2.709(9) Å) are almost equivalent through the series despite the four-fold TEDGA coordination of Th­(IV) in (3) and the higher ionic radius expected for a 12-fold coordinated Th­(IV) compared to a 10-fold one (1.21 Å vs 1.13 Å). These Th–Oether bond values are higher than the mean Th–Ooxalate and Th–Ocarbonyl distances (). The Th–Ooxalate distances, between 2.423(7) and 2.509(2)­Å, are similar to those encountered in the literature for μ2-η2:η2 and μ2-η2 bridging oxalate ligands. The Th–Ocarbonyl bond values are close for compounds (1), (2), and (4). Their values, between 2.421(6) and 2.532(1)­Å, lie within the same range than previously described for carbonyl derivative based compounds. Unlike Th–Oether, the Th–Ocarbonyl bond seems affected by the ionic radius variation of Th­(IV) since compound (3) presents a larger Th–Ocarbonyl mean distance (2.516(6) Å) than compounds (1), (2), and (4) (2.427(8), 2.460(10), and 2.463(5) Å, respectively). These values remain consistent with the Th–Ocarbonyl distances determined by the calculation. So far, only two compounds based on An­(IV)-DGA have been described in the literature: (PuIV(TMDGA)3)­(NO3)3·MCN (TMDGA = tetramethyldiglycolamide; MCN = acetonitrile) and (PuIV(TMDGA)3)­(NO3)3·ETOH. In these examples, the Pu­(IV) cations are surrounded by nine oxygen atoms coming from the three TMDGA, which form a twisted tricapped trigonal prism. The ether oxygen atoms occupy the capping position while the oxygen atoms belonging to the carbonyl function form the summits of the trigonal faces. The Pu–O distances show the same trend than observed in the present study in that the Pu–Oether distances are longer than the Pu–Ocarbonyl distances (∼0.18 Å difference). The Pu–O distance are, on average, ∼0.15–0.19 Å shorter than the Th–O distances which may account for the larger ionic radius of Th­(IV) than Pu­(IV) together with the higher coordination numbers of Th­(IV) in the present compounds than the one of Pu­(IV) in the previously reported PuIV(TMDGA)3)­(NO3)3 solvates. The presence of an additional TEDGA around the thorium cation in (3) may also be related to the larger ionic radius of Th­(IV) than Pu­(IV) (∼0.09 Å difference for a same coordination number), thereby allowing a higher coordination number. The DFT calculations performed by Gong et al. on the thorium-tetramethyldiglycolamide (TMDGA) system showed that the structure of Th­(TMDGA)4 is less stable than the one of Th­(TMDGA)3 due to larger Th–O distances. However, the experimental Th–O distances, more specifically the Th–Oether distances experimentally determined in the present study, are shorter than the calculated distances.

elements.content: In (1), the angle formed by two oxalate parts coordinating Th is of 90°, while it is lower in (2) and (4) with a mean value of about 71° and 80°, respectively (Table S6). The opposite TEDGA ligands coordinating Th in compounds (1), (2), (3), and (4) are turned by an angle varying from 31° to 69° (Table S7). No relationships could be established between the torsion angle of the TEDGA molecules and the dihedral angle formed by their mean planes (Table S8).

elements.content: In all the compounds reported herein, the nitrate anions are found in the interstices, as for instance in (Ln­(TEDGA)3)­(NO3)3·4H2O with Ln = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, and Lu, (Yb­(tris-DGA))­(NO3)3, (Yb­(i-PrDGA)3)­(NO3)4, (PuIV(TMDGA)3)­(NO3)3·MCN, and (PuIV(TMDGA)3)­(NO3)3·ETOH. No solid compounds containing simultaneously nitrate and DGA ligands in the same coordination of the f-element were reported up to date, and the mixed ligands compounds including DGA (L) were only found with the lightest lanthanides, La and Ce. These compounds are heteroleptic, which means that Ln­(NO3)6 polyhedra coexist in the crystal structure besides the Ln­(DGA) n entities leading to (LaL3)­(La­(NO3)6) and (CeL)­(Ce­(NO3)6)­(CH3OH)­(C4H10O) formula. In the present study, the nitrate anions remain close to the thorium cations but do not integrate the coordination sphere. They occupy either the free spaces between the two arms of TEDGA ligands in compounds (1) and (3) (b and c) or the free spaces between the TEDGA ligands in compound (4) (c). According to these structural results and to the crystal structure previously reported, one can assume that the presence of DGA ligands in the coordination sphere of the f-cations preclude the integration of nitrate in the same environment.
elements.clean_text:
Nitrate Positioning

In all the compounds reported herein, the nitrate anions are found in the interstices, as for instance in (Ln(TEDGA)3)(NO3)3⋅4H2O with Ln = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, and Lu, (Yb(tris-DGA))(NO3)3, (Yb(i-PrDGA)3)(NO3)4, (PuIV(TMDGA)3)(NO3)3⋅MCN, and (PuIV(TMDGA)3)(NO3)3⋅ETOH. No solid compounds containing simultaneously nitrate and DGA ligands in the same coordination of the f-element were reported up to date, and the mixed ligands compounds including DGA (L) were only found with the lightest lanthanides, La and Ce. These compounds are heteroleptic, which means that Ln(NO3)6 polyhedra coexist in the crystal structure besides the Ln(DGA) n  entities leading to (LaL3)(La(NO3)6) and (CeL)(Ce(NO3)6)(CH3OH)(C4H10O) formula. In the present study, the nitrate anions remain close to the thorium cations but do not integrate the coordination sphere. They occupy either the free spaces between the two arms of TEDGA ligands in compounds (1) and (3) (b and c) or the free spaces between the TEDGA ligands in compound (4) (c). According to these structural results and to the crystal structure previously reported, one can assume that the presence of DGA ligands in the coordination sphere of the f-cations preclude the integration of nitrate in the same environment.

elements.content: The oxalate ligands coordinating Th­(IV) in compounds (1), (2), and (4) are nearly planar (Table S9). In these oxalate ligands, the C–O distances are slightly different depending upon the bridging mode of the oxalate groups. In the μ2-η2:η2 oxalates, all the C–O distances are equivalent to 1.254(8)­Å, while in the μ2-η2 terminal oxalates the C–O distances with O atoms in the coordination sphere of Th­(IV) tend to be slightly longer (1.271(9)­Å) than the C–O distances with free oxygen atoms (1.234(13)­Å). The oxalic acid molecules can be planar, as the oxalate groups, but their carboxylate plans can also display a twisted angle up to 90°. In the present, compounds the free di- and monoprotonated oxalic acids exhibit a twisted angle varying from 7 to 88°, which shows that the oxalic acid can adopt different geometries (, Table S9). The nomenclature introduced by Nieminen et al. uses the lower case letters c (cis) and t (trans) to describe the relative orientation of the O–H and C–C bonds and the upper letters C (Cis) or T (Trans) to define the relative orientations of the C=O bond. In compound (1), the oxalic acid has a conformation tTt and exhibit a torsion angle, τ, equal to 19°. In compound (2), the two oxalic acids with the same conformations tTt, Ox2 and Ox3, show torsion angles of about 7–8°. In compound (4), different conformations of oxalic acid coexist: the tCt conformation with torsion angles equal to 7, 19, and 88° for the oxalates ox4, ox7, and ox5, respectively, and the tTt conformation for the oxalate ox6 (τ equal to 39°) (). On the basis of these results, it is impossible to establish a relation between the torsion angle and the oxalic acid conformation. However, a careful examination of the C–O distances in compound (4), which crystal structure was solved at 100 K, reveal that the C–O distances around 1.203(5) Å can be attributed to the C=O bonds, while the C–O distances around 1.307(8) Å are related to the C–OH bonds. The 1.3 Å distance characteristic of C–OH is also found in the monoprotonated oxalate ox3 but the standard deviation between C–OH and C–O is lowered ().
elements.clean_text:
Geometry of Free Di- and Monoprotonated Oxalic Acids in (1), (2), and (4)

The oxalate ligands coordinating Th(IV) in compounds (1), (2), and (4) are nearly planar (Table S9). In these oxalate ligands, the C-O distances are slightly different depending upon the bridging mode of the oxalate groups. In the μ2-η2:η2 oxalates, all the C-O distances are equivalent to 1.254(8)Å, while in the μ2-η2 terminal oxalates the C-O distances with O atoms in the coordination sphere of Th(IV) tend to be slightly longer (1.271(9)Å) than the C-O distances with free oxygen atoms (1.234(13)Å). The oxalic acid molecules can be planar, as the oxalate groups, but their carboxylate plans can also display a twisted angle up to 90°. In the present, compounds the free di- and monoprotonated oxalic acids exhibit a twisted angle varying from 7 to 88°, which shows that the oxalic acid can adopt different geometries (, Table S9). The nomenclature introduced by Nieminen et al. uses the lower case letters c (cis) and t (trans) to describe the relative orientation of the O-H and C-C bonds and the upper letters C (Cis) or T (Trans) to define the relative orientations of the C=O bond. In compound (1), the oxalic acid has a conformation tTt and exhibit a torsion angle, τ, equal to 19°. In compound (2), the two oxalic acids with the same conformations tTt, Ox2 and Ox3, show torsion angles of about 7-8°. In compound (4), different conformations of oxalic acid coexist: the tCt conformation with torsion angles equal to 7, 19, and 88° for the oxalates ox4, ox7, and ox5, respectively, and the tTt conformation for the oxalate ox6 (τ equal to 39°) (). On the basis of these results, it is impossible to establish a relation between the torsion angle and the oxalic acid conformation. However, a careful examination of the C-O distances in compound (4), which crystal structure was solved at 100 K, reveal that the C-O distances around 1.203(5) Å can be attributed to the C=O bonds, while the C-O distances around 1.307(8) Å are related to the C-OH bonds. The 1.3 Å distance characteristic of C-OH is also found in the monoprotonated oxalate ox3 but the standard deviation between C-OH and C-O is lowered ().

elements.content: We were able to obtain the compound (1) and (3) as pure powders, the last by modifying the temperature of synthesis. The X-ray diffraction patterns of compounds (1) and (3) and thermal decom position of (3) are shown in Figures S1, S2, and S5, respectively. IR spectra are presented in . Between 4000 and 2000 cm–1, the spectra show the three bands characteristic of the νC–H stretching of the methylene and methyl groups. One can also notice the presence of a large band between 3600 and 3400 cm–1 due to the presence of water molecules in the structures. In the region between 2000 and 400 cm–1, the peak at 1639 cm–1 corresponding to the carbonyl stretching of the TEDGA is shifted at 1612 and 1607 cm–1 in (1) and (3) spectra, respectively, because of the coordination of the TEDGA to the actinide. The C–O–C of the TEDGA exhibits two vibrational bands at 1125 cm–1 (νas) and 1039 cm–1 (νs) for the free ligands. Those bands are slightly shifted due to the coordination of the ether oxygen atom. The bands at 826, 1282, and 1385 cm–1 correspond to the vibrational bands of uncoordinated nitrate anions. The compound (1) spectrum displays one additional band at 1730 cm–1 due to the presence of oxalic acid molecules in the crystal structure. For this compound, the band at 1607 cm–1 might be attributed to the combination of the carbonyl stretching arising from the TEDGA part or to the asymmetric stretching of the oxalate part. The symmetric stretching bands are observed in 1300–1350 cm–1 range.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of Spectroscopic Data for TEDGA, (1), and (3)

We were able to obtain the compound (1) and (3) as pure powders, the last by modifying the temperature of synthesis. The X-ray diffraction patterns of compounds (1) and (3) and thermal decom position of (3) are shown in Figures S1, S2, and S5, respectively. IR spectra are presented in . Between 4000 and 2000 cm-1, the spectra show the three bands characteristic of the νC-H stretching of the methylene and methyl groups. One can also notice the presence of a large band between 3600 and 3400 cm-1 due to the presence of water molecules in the structures. In the region between 2000 and 400 cm-1, the peak at 1639 cm-1 corresponding to the carbonyl stretching of the TEDGA is shifted at 1612 and 1607 cm-1 in (1) and (3) spectra, respectively, because of the coordination of the TEDGA to the actinide. The C-O-C of the TEDGA exhibits two vibrational bands at 1125 cm-1 (νas) and 1039 cm-1 (νs) for the free ligands. Those bands are slightly shifted due to the coordination of the ether oxygen atom. The bands at 826, 1282, and 1385 cm-1 correspond to the vibrational bands of uncoordinated nitrate anions. The compound (1) spectrum displays one additional band at 1730 cm-1 due to the presence of oxalic acid molecules in the crystal structure. For this compound, the band at 1607 cm-1 might be attributed to the combination of the carbonyl stretching arising from the TEDGA part or to the asymmetric stretching of the oxalate part. The symmetric stretching bands are observed in 1300-1350 cm-1 range.

elements.content: Even if the use of diglycolamide molecules for the nuclear waste treatment has been studied for long time, the ability of these organic compounds for complexing the lanthanides or the renewable elements, plutonium, or uranium is still a hot topic, and the knowledge of the different possible phases able to be formed during a process, a very crucial point. The precomplexation of the water-soluble TEDGA and thorium­(IV), followed by an addition of oxalic acid, has allowed to isolate and characterize four new compounds containing Th­(IV) and TEDGA, by successive transformations. Three of them are homoleptic mixed ligands compounds containing two TEDGA and two oxalate in the coordination sphere of Th­(IV), while the fourth compound exhibits four TEDGA in the cation environment leading then to an uncommon coordination number of 12. Although the mixed oxalate-TEDGA ligands compounds present the same coordination sphere, the dimensionality of the networks varies from linear chains to isolated entities or dimeric units. The TEDGA molecule shows then a great ability to complex the actinide cation (thorium in the present case) despite the presence of oxalic acid. The influence that TEDGA might have on the structural and microstructural properties of the precipitate during the next step of the industrial process, that is, the oxalic precipitation is under study by carrying out oxalic precipitation and crystal growth of Th­(C2O4)2·6H2O and Pu­(C2O4)2·6H2O in the presence of TEDGA.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Even if the use of diglycolamide molecules for the nuclear waste treatment has been studied for long time, the ability of these organic compounds for complexing the lanthanides or the renewable elements, plutonium, or uranium is still a hot topic, and the knowledge of the different possible phases able to be formed during a process, a very crucial point. The precomplexation of the water-soluble TEDGA and thorium(IV), followed by an addition of oxalic acid, has allowed to isolate and characterize four new compounds containing Th(IV) and TEDGA, by successive transformations. Three of them are homoleptic mixed ligands compounds containing two TEDGA and two oxalate in the coordination sphere of Th(IV), while the fourth compound exhibits four TEDGA in the cation environment leading then to an uncommon coordination number of 12. Although the mixed oxalate-TEDGA ligands compounds present the same coordination sphere, the dimensionality of the networks varies from linear chains to isolated entities or dimeric units. The TEDGA molecule shows then a great ability to complex the actinide cation (thorium in the present case) despite the presence of oxalic acid. The influence that TEDGA might have on the structural and microstructural properties of the precipitate during the next step of the industrial process, that is, the oxalic precipitation is under study by carrying out oxalic precipitation and crystal growth of Th(C2O4)2⋅6H2O and Pu(C2O4)2⋅6H2O in the presence of TEDGA.

cln_elements.content: Compound (3) was obtained as a pure phase by adding thorium nitrate (0.2 mmol), TEDGA (0.8 mmol), and oxalic acid (50 mg) to 10 mL of deionized water, at room temperature. Solid oxalic acid was used in place of oxalic acid solution to favor slow diffusion and then achieve a better crystal growth. The colorless solution obtained after adding all the reactants was left under the hood. After 10 days, a precipitate matching the X-ray powder diffraction pattern of compound (3) was obtained (Figure S2) with a yield of 25%. This pure powder was afterward used to perform further chemical analysis.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Pure [Th(TEDGA)4[NO3]4⋅4H2O (3)

Compound (3) was obtained as a pure phase by adding thorium nitrate (0.2 mmol), TEDGA (0.8 mmol), and oxalic acid (50 mg) to 10 mL of deionized water, at room temperature. Solid oxalic acid was used in place of oxalic acid solution to favor slow diffusion and then achieve a better crystal growth. The colorless solution obtained after adding all the reactants was left under the hood. After 10 days, a precipitate matching the X-ray powder diffraction pattern of compound (3) was obtained (Figure S2) with a yield of 25%. This pure powder was afterward used to perform further chemical analysis.

cln_elements.content: Micrographs of the single-crystals appearing in a viscous solution containing thorium nitrate, TEDGA, and oxalic acid left at room temperature. (a) After 10 days, compound (1), in red, crystallizes; (b) five weeks later, a mixture of (2), in violet, and (3), in green, is formed; (c) after four months, a mixture of rod-like crystals (1), in red, and blocks (4), in yellow, is obtained.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Micrographs of the single-crystals appearing in a viscous solution containing thorium nitrate, TEDGA, and oxalic acid left at room temperature. (a) After 10 days, compound (1), in red, crystallizes; (b) five weeks later, a mixture of (2), in violet, and (3), in green, is formed; (c) after four months, a mixture of rod-like crystals (1), in red, and blocks (4), in yellow, is obtained.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]­[NO3]2[H2C2O4]·6H2O (1). (a) 10-fold coordination of Th. (b) Syn–syn and syn–anti conformation of the TEDGA ethyl-groups. (c) [Th­(TEDGA)2(C2O4)]2+ ∞ chains running along the c axis and maintained in a three-dimensional arrangement by means of a H-bond network (blue dotted lines) involving the nitrate anions, (d) oxalic acid and water molecules. Legend: Th4+ coordination polyhedra are in purple, C in gray, O in red, and N in blue. The black arrows show the orientation of the ethyl groups over the plane defined by N–C–C atoms: full line, up; dotted line, down. The TEDGA molecules were removed for clarity in the H-network representation.

(c) [Th­(TEDGA)4]4+ entities surrounded by four nitrate anions, and (d) maintained in a three-dimensional arrangement thanks to the electrostatic interactions and the H-bond network (blue dotted lines) between the nitrate anions and the water molecules. cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]­[NO3]­[HC2O4]­[H2C2O4]4·7H2O (4). (a) 10-fold coordination of Th. (b) Syn–syn and syn–anti conformation of the TEDGA ethyl-groups. (c) Dimeric units [Th2(C2O4)3(TEDGA)4]2+ surrounded by the nitrate groups and (d) maintained in a three-dimensional arrangement by means of a H-bond network (blue dotted lines) between the nitrate anions, oxalic acid, and water molecules. Legend: Th4+ coordination polyhedra are in purple, C in gray, O in red, and N in blue. The black arrows show the orientation of the ethyl groups over the plane defined by N–C–C atoms: full line, up; dotted line, down. The TEDGA molecules were removed for clarity in the H-network representation.
